brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine if progesterone treatment safely reduces brain
      swelling and damage after injury.

clinical_study.brief_title: Progesterone Treatment of Blunt Traumatic Brain Injury

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Blunt head trauma occuring within 11 hours

          -  Ages 18 years and older (or Tanner Score of 5)

          -  Index GCS between 4 and 12

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Spinal cord injury

          -  Penetrating head trauma

          -  Cardiopulmonary arrest upon ECC arrival

          -  Status Epilepticus upon ECC arrival

          -  Systolic BP < 90mmHG upon ECC arrival

          -  Pulse Ox of < 90 (or pO2 < 60)

          -  Prisoners or incarcerated individuals

          -  Past Hx of significant intercranial pathology

          -  Pregnant females

          -  Blood alcohol level > 250 mg/dl

          -  Non-English speakers (a Spanish version of the ICF is currently being developed)

          -  Allergy(s) to soy, egg, or progesterone

          -  Active breast or reproductive organ cancer(s)

          -  Previous head injury or stroke within the past 6 weeks

facility.name: Emory University School of Medicine - Dept. of Emergency Medicine

clinical_study.official_title: ProTECT: Single Center, Phase II (Pilot), Double Blind, 4:1 Randomized, Placebo Controlled Clinical Trial for Progesterone Treatment of Moderate and Severe Blunt TBI

overall_official.affiliation: Chairman - Emory University Dept. of Emergency Medicine

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration
United States: Data and Safety Monitoring Board

reference.citation: Wright DW, Clark PL, Pentz RD, Hertzberg V, Kellermann AL. Enrolling subjects by exception from consent versus proxy consent in trauma care research. Ann Emerg Med. 2008 Apr;51(4):355-60, 360.e1-3. Epub 2007 Oct 15.

ProTECT: a randomized clinical trial of progesterone for acute traumatic brain injury. Ann Emerg Med. 2007 Apr;49(4):391-402, 402.e1-2. Epub 2006 Sep 29.

Wright DW, Ritchie JC, Mullins RE, Kellermann AL, Denson DD. Steady-state serum concentrations of progesterone following continuous intravenous infusion in patients with acute moderate to severe traumatic brain injury. J Clin Pharmacol. 2005 Jun;45(6):640-8.

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)
